property_values.ai_title: The Dear Evan Hansen Movie and Musical Analysis

summary: The video discusses the musical Dear Evan Hansen and its recent film adaptation. The speaker analyzes what went wrong with the movie and how the stage production's themes and characters were lost in translation. The musical, which swept Broadway in 2015, tells the story of Evan Hansen, a high school student struggling with anxiety and mental health issues. The show's success and popularity, particularly among teens, led to a backlash against its perceived overrated status and the teen fandom that developed around it.

The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen has several issues, including poor casting choices, particularly with Ben Platt playing Evan Hansen at an age that doesn't align with the character's high school age. The film also struggles with translating the stage show's themes and characters to the screen, resulting in a story that feels incongruous and manipulative. The music in the film is also problematic, with added songs feeling shoehorned and generic. The adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen from stage to screen faced significant challenges, particularly in terms of song selection and narrative changes.

The film's attempt to expand on certain characters, like Alana, fell flat, and the removal of key songs like 'Does Anybody Have a Map?' and 'Good For You' altered the story's themes and character development. The film's changes, including a new ending and character modifications, detracted from the original story, prioritizing Evan's emotions over Connor's. The speaker discusses the challenges of adapting stage musicals to film, using Dear Evan Hansen and The Last 5 Years as examples.

They highlight the differences between stage and screen, particularly in conveying the passage of time and musical numbers. The speaker argues that directors must make deliberate choices to translate the stage show's intent to film, but sometimes these choices can fall flat. The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen has been criticized for its poor direction, tone, and translation from stage to screen. The movie's attempts to ground the story in realism and emphasize emotional impact come across as forced and tasteless.

The film's use of long static medium shots and lack of comedic elements detract from the story. The adaptation's focus on award recognition has led to a loss of the stage show's dark comedy and charm. The speaker discusses the impact of Stephen Sondheim's work on musical theater and the current state of movie musicals. They express concern that film adaptations often reject what makes musicals unique, such as strong choreography and emotionally explosive numbers.

A lot of this is a difference in perceived realism. In a stage production, you don't necessarily need to believe that the space people are occupying is a real space because, well, you'd know it's not. You're there observing a performance. You are watching people perform in a box in front of you.

They exist in the same physical space that you do. That means that a lot of the staging and production of stage shows are more abstract, I guess is the best word. They can play around more with the environment such as how Hamilton's set is a mostly static wooden room with a few props brought in every now and then. You can play with time like having a character finish 1 scene and then transition into another scene without that character leaving the stage at all or anything else that would give the theoretical idea of a scene ending.

Think of how Come From Away has most of its cast on stage for the entirety of its show and just transitions effortlessly between moment to moment. But I think 1 of the most important things unique to theater is the way that a character interacts with the fourth wall. The fourth wall thing is quite interesting because it's a small matter that really does have a large effect on the overall perception of the work. For those who don't know, the fourth wall in a stage production refers to the fourth wall that would exist in a set.

Considering how theater has to be observable and cheated out toward an audience, rooms can't be closed and contained the same way they are in real life. So a room in a stage show has a back wall, 2 side walls, and nothing else. What would be the fourth wall is the audience. And in a stage show, you can easily play with that.

Because there is the unavoidable perception that this is all being performed to a crowd, you can simply have your actors, well, perform to the crowd. I don't necessarily mean direct interactions, like calling out to them or mingling with them the way a musician might at a concert, though that certainly could happen. But it's more because of the fact that you're aware you're being performed to, the actor, if they wanted to, could just stand there and, well, perform to you. No need for a lot of stage business or sometimes even a background.

You can just have the characters sing to the crowd amongst an backdrop, and you're fine, and it gets the job done, and it works. But that doesn't work in a film. Not really. The problem is that while the fourth wall in a stage show is the audience, the fourth wall in a film is the camera.

And then later, the audience will watch what the camera captured. And because of our underlying notion of cameras and how they work and what their purpose is, we generally expect them to record something matching close to reality. I don't mean that we expect everything that we see on film to actually be capable of happening in real life. Like, it's not like we're all watching Dune and going, this is bullshit.

Worms aren't actually that big. However, there is this sort of idea that what we're seeing in frame is something that exists in the world of that frame, and the world of that frame needs to seem like enough of a believable world to us. It's generally why you don't see as much abstraction in film as you do in theater, at least outside of art films. It's also why effects and props tend to get called out for not looking realistic more in film than they do in theater.
